In Julia, Write a function `ispersonal` that returns a trait if the provided Vehicle type is a personal vehicle for everyday driving. All vehicles are subtypes of AbstractVehicle. Function must work for types: Car, Motorcycle, Bus, Truck. The first two should return true, the latter two should return false . The function should default to false for any other subtype of AbstractVehicle. Provide an example.

In Julia, you can define a trait using abstract types and multiple dispatch. Below is an example implementation of the `ispersonal` function that adheres to these requirements:

```julia
abstract type AbstractVehicle end

struct Car <: AbstractVehicle end
struct Motorcycle <: AbstractVehicle end
struct Bus <: AbstractVehicle end
struct Truck <: AbstractVehicle end

function ispersonal(vehicle::AbstractVehicle)
    if typeof(vehicle) <: Car || typeof(vehicle) <: Motorcycle
        return true
    elseif typeof(vehicle) <: Bus || typeof(vehicle) <: Truck
        return false
    end
    return false
end

# Example usage:
julia> ispersonal(Car())  # Should return true
true

julia> ispersonal(Motorcycle())  # Should return true
true

julia> ispersonal(Bus())  # Should return false
false

julia> ispersonal(Truck())  # Should return false
false

julia> ispersonal(CarLight())  # Should return false (if CarLight is not defined as a subtype of AbstractVehicle)
false
```

In this example, `AbstractVehicle` is an abstract type representing all vehicles. `Car`, `Motorcycle`, `Bus`, and `Truck` are concrete types that are subtypes of `AbstractVehicle`. The `ispersonal` function uses multiple dispatch to determine if a vehicle is personal based on its type. It returns `true` for cars and motorcycles because they are typically used for everyday driving by individuals. For buses and trucks, it returns `false` since these are usually not used for personal transportation. For any other subtype of `AbstractVehicle` or for types that are not directly related to vehicles, the function defaults to `false`.
